tutorial.title: Milla's Motos
tutorial.descriptionContent: Use CSS Flexbox to align elements on a motorcycle website

executableContent.instructions:
You've been hired to fix some problems for a local motorcycle dealer's website. 

Take a look at the code and its preview. At first glance, the site does not look bad. But the navigation and partner links are all lined up on the vertical axis. Your client wants them aligned horizontally. 

The partner links and final promotion pictures are in reverse order. The specification asks that you fix these issues with flexbox. 

There are no tests here. Move on to the next lesson to begin after you look at the existing code.

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: You need to code the `display` property in the `.container` rule with the appropriate value for flexbox.

executableContent.instructions:
Great, now the page is becoming more organized. But there's a problem with the margin around the borders. This is because browsers assign default values to things like margin. Many developers use a **CSS Reset** to remove these defaults.


It's a good idea to remove the margin default in most cases. You need to do that, in this case, to clean up the appearance of the page and avoid any problems if we need to adjust the margin for specific elements later.

1. Reset the `margin` property's value to `0` in the existing `body` ruleset.

executableContent.instructions:
The HTML and the client's desired design of the website show that the navigation is the first flexbox container on the site. In the HTML there are two classes associated with this container. 

The unique class found next to the `container` class needs a ruleset in the CSS that'll define the main axis and direction of the navigation items on the cross axis. You won't see a change in the site because the value we'll code is the default one. We're just coding it for practice.

1. Code an empty ruleset with the unique class selector for the navigation bar.
2. Code the property in the rule that's used to define the main axis and direction of flex items.
3. Code the default value of that property.

executableContent.instructions:
The navigation links could overflow on smaller phones. We haven't covered this, but a quick fix here would be to allow the content that would overflow to wrap down to a second row. The property `flex-wrap` does this. By default, it's set to `nowrap`. 

1. In the `.navigation` ruleset code the property `flex-wrap` and give it the value `wrap`.

executableContent.instructions:
Next are the photos. The photos are displayed in a column as desired with the starter code. But adding `display: flex` left all flex containers arranging their items with the default value of `row`. This default makes the main axis horizontal and fixed the navigation bar. But now we need to arrange the photos on the vertical axis, starting from the top.

1. Code an empty rule with the unique class selector for the photos found in the first promotion section.
2. Code the property that controls the flex direction with the value that will define the main axis of the photos as vertical and the content ordered on the cross axis starting from the top.

executableContent.instructions:
Next are the links to the partner sites. The class we need already exists in the CSS. 

The first problem we'll need to tackle is the ordering of the items. The order of the links is reversed compared to the client's wishes because of the order they appear in the HTML. Per the specification, we can fix this with the CSS. Fortunately, flexbox gives us a solution for this problem.

1. Code the property that controls the flex direction. Give it the value that makes the main axis horizontal and with the content ordered in reverse, relative to the cross axis.

executableContent.instructions:
The links are in the order desired by the client. But now, as expected, because `row-reverse` starts from the right side of the page, the items are still not in the desired position. Once again, we're fortunate that flexbox has a solution for this. 

We can justify the content to the right, left, and center with the property `justify-content`. You haven't yet learned this property, but you can see how useful it is.

1. Code the value `center` for the property `justify-content` inside the ruleset for the `.partners` class.

executableContent.instructions:
Now you need to fix the other promotional photos. The problem again is that the photos are in the reverse order that the client desires. Again, flexbox has a solution for this.

1. Code the flex direction property in the `otherPromo` class with the value that'll define the main axis of the photos as vertical and the content ordered in reverse on the cross axis, starting from the bottom of the page.

executableContent.instructions:
There is one last issue. Look at the page.

Because `row reverse` starts at the bottom of the cross axis, and the height of the last flex container is fixed at 600px, there is extra space above the pictures. You don't need to adjust the `margin` property. But you need to adjust the `height` so that everything is uniform. Sometimes you might make educated guesses to get close to the proper value, or do calculations to find it. In this case, we'll give you the right value. Great work, you should take a look at all you have done!

1. Replace the value of the `height` property in the `otherPromo` ruleset with `540px`.
